section.title: Dividing map into "chapters"
section.p: Out of the box, the DITA OT processes the map into map-like structures (TOC, index.html, and so on). Then each of the DITA topics subordinate to the map are processed, without further reference to the map. When creating the XHTML output, we want to pull all chapters together and output each of them as a "whole" HTML page. So, we need a different way of driving the HTML transforms.

There are several approaches to drive the creation of chapters.
Create a series of sub maps from the DITA map or bookmap file, then process each in turn.
Use the DITA map or bookmap file and the xsl:result-document directive.
Use the topicmerge transform from the ODT or FO transtype, then use xsl:result-document when processing the merged file.

section.title: HTML backmatter
section.p: It would be nice to be able to use the <backmatter> element to semantically contain the closing information in the bookmap for an XHMTL document. However, there are several factors that make that difficult. Prime among those is the fact that the backmatter doesn't allow a navtitle attribute or element.

As things stand, to have a final chapter that encloses an "About" statement, related publications, trademark and copyright notices, and additional statements (such as the OEM statement), is a much more workable (and localizable) solution.

section.title: Revision history in XHTML and PDF
section.p: The differences in processing XHMTL and PDF documents require two different ways of specifying where to insert the revision history table.

In PDF bookmaps, the <frontmatter> element should contain a <trademarklist> element. The href in the <trademarklist> element indicates the file containing the trademark information. The PDF plugin recognizes the <trademarklist> element and automatically adds the revision history to p.ii of the document.

In XHTML output, there are two different ways you can use to indicate where to place the revision history table.
In the DITA topic containing the trademark information, assign an outputclass attribute with the value "trademark" to the <topic> element. The plugin will then insert the revision history table at the end of this document.
If you need to insert the revision history table at a specific location in the trademark topic (say between two specific paragraphs, or at the beginning of the trademark topic), add an empty <bodydiv/> element with outputclass="revisions" where you want the plugin to insert the revision history table.

section.title: Notes
section.p: I've used @otherprops in the <vrm> element for the page number that changed. However, I would advise against continuing this practice (identifying the page that changed), because it's meaningful only in the PDF (and possibly only meaningful in the en-us version).

section.title: Graphics
section.p: For each PNG graphic used in a deliverable, export an SVG of the same image and make it available in the same folder as the PNG graphics. If you don't want a figure to link to an SVG, use outputclass="nolink"
